title: When to Transform a Model
question_text:
Which of the statements is/are true regarding transforming a model involving an explanatory and response relationship?

I. One should consider transforming the data if the residual plot of residuals on $X$ fails to show a pattern.
II. One should consider transforming the data if the scatterplot of $X$ against $Y$ shows a curved pattern.
III. One should consider transforming the data if the correlation coefficient, $r$, is $-0.30$.
solution:
Statement I is incorrect; if the original model is the best model available, the residual plot should show no pattern.

Statement II is correct; if the original plot shows a curved pattern, it is likely the form is exponential.

Statement III is incorrect; some models will simply have a weak correlation, regardless of any transformations. This could indicate either a weak correlation or that a transformation is needed. A plot of the residuals will give a better indication of whether or not a transformation is needed.

Thus, the correct answer is Choice 'B'.
